<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=38,EFW="2182865",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=1018001,FOLIO='36',FILE='DISK124:[08ZAH1.08ZAH70301]DK70301A.;46',USER='MANDERS',CD='26-FEB-2008;05:22' -->
<A NAME="page_dk70301_1_37"> </A>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(5)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>"Minority
Interest" reflects the ownership interest in the Operating Partnership not owned by the Company.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(6)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Assumes
that all OP Units and Westcor partnership units are converted to common stock on a one-for-one basis. The Westcor partnership units were converted into
OP Units on July&nbsp;27, 2004, which were subsequently redeemed for common stock on October&nbsp;4, 2005. It also assumes the conversion of MACWH,&nbsp;LP common and preferred units to the
extent that they are dilutive to the EPS computation (See Note&nbsp;12&#151;Acquisitions in the Company's Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements).
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(7)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Includes
the dilutive effect of share and unit-based compensation plans and convertible senior notes calculated using the treasury stock method and the dilutive effect of all other
dilutive securities calculated using the "if converted" method.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(8)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company issued PCPUs on April&nbsp;25, 2005 as part of the consideration paid for the Wilmorite portfolio. On January&nbsp;1, 2008, the PCPUs were redeemed for the Rochester
Properties (See Note&nbsp;25--Subsequent Events in the Company's Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements).
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(9)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>On
October&nbsp;18, 2007, the holder of the Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock converted 560,000 shares to common shares.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(10)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company uses FFO in addition to net income to report its operating and financial results and considers FFO and FFO--diluted as supplemental measures for the real estate industry
and a supplement to Generally Accepted Accounting Principles ("GAAP") measures. The National Association of Real Estate Investment Trusts ("NAREIT") defines FFO as net income (loss) (computed in
accordance with GAAP), excluding gains (or losses) from extraordinary items and sales of depreciated operating properties, plus real estate related depreciation and amortization and after adjustments
for unconsolidated partnerships and joint ventures. Adjustments for unconsolidated partnerships and joint ventures are calculated to reflect FFO on the same basis. FFO and FFO on a fully diluted basis
are useful to investors in comparing operating and financial results between periods. This is especially true since FFO excludes real estate depreciation and amortization as the Company believes real
estate values fluctuate based on market conditions rather than depreciating in value ratably on a straight-line basis over time. FFO on a fully diluted basis is one of the measures
investors find most useful in measuring the dilutive impact of outstanding convertible securities. FFO does not represent cash flow from operations as defined by GAAP, should not be considered as an
alternative to net income as defined by GAAP and is not indicative of cash available to fund all cash flow needs. FFO as presented may not be comparable to similarly titled measures reported by other
real estate investment trusts. For the reconciliation of FFO and FFO&#151;diluted to net income, see "Item&nbsp;7. Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of
Operations--Funds from Operations." </FONT></DD></DL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The computation of FFO-diluted includes the effect of share and unit-based compensation plans and convertible senior notes calculated using the
treasury stock method. It also assumes the conversion of MACWH,&nbsp;LP common and preferred units and all other securities to the extent that they are dilutive to the FFO computation (See
Note&nbsp;12--Acquisitions of the Company's Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements). On February&nbsp;25, 1998, the Company sold $100&nbsp;million of its Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock.
On June&nbsp;16, 1998, the Company sold $150&nbsp;million of its Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock. The Preferred Stock can be converted on a one-for-one basis for common
stock. The Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock then outstanding was dilutive to FFO in 2007, 2006, 2005, 2004 and 2003 and was dilutive to net income in 2006 and 2003. All of the Series&nbsp;B Preferred
Stock was converted to common stock on September&nbsp;9, 2003. The Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock then outstanding was dilutive to FFO and net income in
2003.</FONT></P>

</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>37</FONT></P>

<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_dm70301_1_38"> </A>

<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"Black" -->


<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"font-family:times;" -->

 </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> <A NAME="dm70301_item_7._management_s_discussio__ite03668"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dm70301_1"> </A>
ITEM 7.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Management's Overview and Summary  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company is involved in the acquisition, ownership, development, redevelopment, management and leasing of regional and community shopping centers located
throughout the United States. The Company is the sole general partner of, and owns a majority of the ownership interests in, the Operating Partnership. As of December&nbsp;31, 2007, the Operating
Partnership owned or had an ownership interest in 74 regional shopping centers and 20 community shopping centers aggregating approximately 80.7&nbsp;million square feet of GLA. These 94 regional and
community shopping centers are referred to hereinafter as the "Centers", unless the context otherwise requires. The Company is a self-administered and self-managed REIT and
conducts all of its operations through the Operating Partnership and the Company's Management Companies. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following discussion is based primarily on the consolidated financial statements of the Company for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007, 2006 and 2005. It compares the results
of operations and cash flows for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 to the results of operations and cash flows for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006. Also included is a comparison of the
results of operations and cash flows for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 to the results of operations and cash flows for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005. This information should be
read in conjunction with the accompanying consolidated financial statements and notes thereto. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Acquisitions and Dispositions:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The financial statements reflect the following acquisitions, dispositions and changes in ownership subsequent to the occurrence of each transaction. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
January&nbsp;5, 2005, the Company sold Arizona Lifestyle Galleries for $4.3&nbsp;million. The sale resulted in a gain on sale on asset of $0.3&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
January&nbsp;11, 2005, the Company became a 15% owner in a joint venture that acquired Metrocenter Mall, a 1.1&nbsp;million square foot super-regional mall in Phoenix, Arizona.
The total purchase price was $160&nbsp;million and concurrently with the acquisition, the joint venture placed a $112&nbsp;million loan on the property. The Company's share of the purchase price,
net of the debt, was $7.2&nbsp;million which was funded by cash and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
January&nbsp;21, 2005, the Company formed a 50/50 joint venture with a private investment company. The joint venture acquired a 49% interest in Kierland Commons, a 435,022 square
foot mixed-use center in Phoenix, Arizona. The joint venture's purchase price for the interest in the Center was $49.0&nbsp;million. The Company assumed its share of the underlying
property debt and funded the remainder of its share of the purchase price by cash and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
April&nbsp;8, 2005, the Company acquired Ridgmar Mall, a 1.3&nbsp;million square foot super-regional mall in Fort Worth, Texas. The acquisition was completed in a 50/50 joint
venture with an affiliate of Walton Street Capital,&nbsp;LLC. The purchase price was $71.1&nbsp;million. Concurrent with the closing, a $57.4&nbsp;million loan bearing interest at a fixed rate
of 6.0725% was placed on the property. The balance of the purchase price was funded by borrowings under the Company's line of credit. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
April&nbsp;25, 2005, the Company and the Operating Partnership acquired Wilmorite Properties,&nbsp;Inc., a Delaware corporation ("Wilmorite"), and Wilmorite Holdings,&nbsp;L.P.,
a Delaware limited partnership ("Wilmorite Holdings"). Wilmorite's portfolio included interests in 11 regional malls and two open-air community shopping centers with 13.4&nbsp;million
square feet of space located in Connecticut, New York, New Jersey, Kentucky and Virginia. The total purchase price was </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>38</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=40,EFW="2182865",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=904494,FOLIO='38',FILE='DISK124:[08ZAH1.08ZAH70301]DM70301A.;30',USER='KYANGB',CD='26-FEB-2008;20:06' -->
<A NAME="page_dm70301_1_39"> </A>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>approximately
$2.3&nbsp;billion, plus adjustments for working capital, including the assumption of approximately $877.2&nbsp;million of existing debt with an average interest rate of 6.43% and the
issuance of $212.7&nbsp;million of PCPUs, $21.5&nbsp;million of non-participating convertible preferred units and $5.8&nbsp;million of common units in Wilmorite Holdings. The balance
of the consideration to the equity holders of Wilmorite and Wilmorite Holdings was paid in cash, which was provided primarily by a five-year, $450&nbsp;million term loan bearing interest
at LIBOR plus 1.50% and a $650&nbsp;million acquisition loan with a term of up to two years and bearing interest initially at LIBOR plus 1.60%. An affiliate of the Operating Partnership is the
general partner and, together with other affiliates, owned as of December&nbsp;31, 2007 approximately 83% of Wilmorite Holdings, with the remaining 17% held by those limited partners of Wilmorite
Holdings who elected to receive convertible preferred units or common units in Wilmorite Holdings rather than cash. On January&nbsp;1, 2008, the PCPUs were redeemed for the Rochester Properties. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Wilmorite portfolio, exclusive of Tysons Corner Center and Tysons Corner Office (collectively referred herein as "Tysons Center"), are referred to herein as the "2005 Acquisition
Centers." </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
February&nbsp;1, 2006, the Company acquired Valley River Center, an 910,841 square foot super-regional mall in Eugene, Oregon. The total purchase price was $187.5&nbsp;million and
concurrent with the acquisition, the Company placed a $100.0&nbsp;million ten-year loan on the property. The balance of the purchase price was funded by cash and borrowings under the
Company's line of credit. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
June&nbsp;9, 2006, the Company sold Scottsdale/101, a 564,000 square foot center in Phoenix, Arizona. The sale price was $117.6&nbsp;million from which $56.0&nbsp;million was
used to payoff the mortgage on the property. The Company's share of the realized gain was $25.8&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
July&nbsp;13, 2006, the Company sold Park Lane Mall, a 370,000 square foot center in Reno, Nevada, for $20&nbsp;million resulting in a gain of $5.9&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
July&nbsp;26, 2006, the Company purchased 11 department stores located in 10 of its Centers from Federated Department Stores,&nbsp;Inc. for approximately $100.0&nbsp;million.
The purchase price consisted of a $93.0&nbsp;million cash payment at closing and a $7.0&nbsp;million cash payment in 2007, in connection with development work by Federated at the Company's
development properties. The Company's share of the purchase price was $81.0&nbsp;million and was funded in part from the proceeds of sales of Park Lane Mall, Greeley Mall, Holiday Village and Great
Falls Marketplace, and from borrowings under the
Company's line of credit. The balance of the purchase price was paid by the Company's joint venture partners. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
July&nbsp;27, 2006, the Company sold Holiday Village, a 498,000 square foot center in Great Falls, Montana, and Greeley Mall, a 564,000 square foot center in Greeley, Colorado, in a
combined sale for $86.8&nbsp;million, resulting in a gain of $28.7&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
August&nbsp;11, 2006, the Company sold Great Falls Marketplace, a 215,000 square foot community center in Great Falls, Montana, for $27.5&nbsp;million resulting in a gain of
$11.8&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
December&nbsp;1, 2006, the Company acquired Deptford Mall, a two-level&nbsp;1.0&nbsp;million square foot super-regional mall in Deptford, New Jersey. The total
purchase price of $240.1&nbsp;million was funded by cash and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. On December&nbsp;7, 2006, the Company placed a $100.0&nbsp;million
six-year loan bearing interest at a fixed rate of 5.44% on the property. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
December&nbsp;29, 2006, the Company sold Citadel Mall, a 1,095,000 square foot center in Colorado Springs, Colorado, Crossroads Mall, a 1,268,000 square foot center in Oklahoma
City, Oklahoma, and Northwest Arkansas Mall, a 820,000 square foot center in Fayetteville, Arkansas, in a combined sale for $373.8&nbsp;million, resulting in a gain of $132.7&nbsp;million. The net
proceeds were used to pay down the Company's line of credit and pay off the Company's $75.0&nbsp;million loan on Paradise Valley Mall. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>39</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=41,EFW="2182865",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=661890,FOLIO='39',FILE='DISK124:[08ZAH1.08ZAH70301]DM70301A.;30',USER='KYANGB',CD='26-FEB-2008;20:06' -->
<A NAME="page_dm70301_1_40"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Valley
River Center and Deptford Mall are referred to herein as the "2006 Acquisition Centers." </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
September&nbsp;5, 2007, the Company purchased the remaining 50% outside ownership interest in Hilton Village, a 96,546 square foot specialty center in Scottsdale, Arizona. The total
purchase price of $13.5&nbsp;million was funded by cash, borrowings under the Company's line of credit and the assumption of a mortgage note payable. The Center was previously accounted for under
the equity method as an investment in unconsolidated joint ventures. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
December&nbsp;17, 2007, the Company purchased a portfolio of ground leasehold interest and/or fee interests in 39 freestanding Mervyn's stores located in the Southwest United
States. The purchase price of $400.2&nbsp;million was funded by cash and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. At acquisition,
management designated the 27 freestanding stores located at shopping centers not owned or managed by the Company as available for sale. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Hilton
Village and the 12 Mervyn's freestanding stores that have not been designated as available for sale are referred herein as the "2007 Acquisition Properties." </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Redevelopments and Developments:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The first phase of SanTan Village Regional Center opened on October&nbsp;26, 2007. The 1.2&nbsp;million square foot open-air super-regional
shopping center opened with over 90% of the retail space committed, with Dillard's and more than 85 specialty retailers joining Harkins Theatres, which opened March 2007. The balance of the project,
which includes Dick's Sporting Goods, Best Buy, Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble and up to 13 restaurants, is expected to open in phases throughout 2008. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
first phase of The Promenade at Casa Grande, a 1&nbsp;million square foot, 130 acre department store anchored hybrid center, located in Casa Grande, Arizona, opened on
November&nbsp;16, 2007. With ninety percent committed, the first phase of the project has approximately 550,000 square feet of mini-majors, including Dillard's, Target, J.C.Penney,
Kohl's, Petsmart and Staples. The balance of the Center is expected to continue to open in phases throughout 2008. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
first phase of The Marketplace at Flagstaff Mall, a 435,000 square foot lifestyle expansion began opening in phases on October&nbsp;19, 2007. Phase&nbsp;I delivered approximately
267,538 square feet of new retail space including Best Buy, Home Depot, Linens n Things, Marshalls, Old Navy, Petco and Shoe Pavilion. Phase&nbsp;II, which will consist of village shops, an
entertainment plaza and pad space, is expected to be completed in 2009-2010. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
November&nbsp;8, 2007, Freehold Raceway Mall opened the first phase of a combined expansion and renovation project that will add 96,000 square feet of new retail and restaurant uses
to this regional center in New Jersey. The expansion, which is 85% committed, added nine new-to-market additions including: Borders, The Cheesecake Factory, P.F. Chang's, Jared
The Galleria of Jewelry, The Territory Ahead, Ann Taylor, Chico's, Coldwater Creek and White House/Black Market. The balance of the project is expected to open throughout 2008. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Scottsdale
Fashion Square, the 2&nbsp;million square foot luxury flagship, is undergoing a $130&nbsp;million redevelopment and expansion. Phase&nbsp;I of the redevelopment and
expansion began September 2007 with demolition of the vacant anchor space acquired as a result of the Federated-May merger and an adjacent parking structure. A 60,000 square foot Barneys
New York, the high-end retailer's first Arizona location, will anchor an additional 100,000 square feet of
up to 30 new luxury shops, which is planned to open in Fall 2009 in an urban setting on Scottsdale Road. New first-to-market deals include Salvatore Ferragamo, Grand Luxe
Caf&eacute;, CH Carolina Herrera, and Michael Kors. First-to-market retailers opening in the Spring 2008 will include Bottega Veneta, Jimmy Choo and Marciano. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Construction
continues on the combined redevelopment, expansion and interior renovation of The Oaks, an upscale 1.0&nbsp;million square foot super-regional shopping center in
California's affluent </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>40</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=42,EFW="2182865",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=127786,FOLIO='40',FILE='DISK124:[08ZAH1.08ZAH70301]DM70301A.;30',USER='KYANGB',CD='26-FEB-2008;20:06' -->
<A NAME="page_dm70301_1_41"> </A>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Thousand
Oaks. The market's first Nordstrom department store is under construction. Construction of a first-to-market, 138,000 square foot Nordstrom Department Store,
two-level open-air retail, dining and entertainment venue and new multi-level parking structure at The Oaks continues on schedule toward a phased completion beginning Fall
2008. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
December 2007, the Company received full entitlements to proceed with plans for a redevelopment of Santa Monica Place. The regional center will be redeveloped as an
open-air shopping and dining environment that will connect with the popular Third Street Promenade. The Santa Monica Place redevelopment has started and is moving forward with a projected
Fall 2009 completion. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Inflation:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the last three years, inflation has not had a significant impact on the Company because of a relatively low inflation rate. Most of the leases at the Centers
have rent adjustments periodically through the lease term. These rent increases are either in fixed increments or based on using an annual multiple of increases in the Consumer Price Index ("CPI"). In
addition, about 6%-13% of the leases expire each year, which enables the Company to replace existing leases with new leases at higher base rents if the rents of the existing leases are
below the then existing market rate. Additionally, historically the majority of the leases required the tenants to pay their pro rata share of operating expenses. In January 2005, the Company began
entering into leases that require tenants to pay a stated amount for operating expenses, generally excluding property taxes, regardless of the expenses actually incurred at any Center. This change
shifts the burden of cost control to the Company. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Seasonality:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The shopping center industry is seasonal in nature, particularly in the fourth quarter during the holiday season when retailer occupancy and retail sales are
typically at their highest levels. In addition, shopping malls achieve a substantial portion of their specialty (temporary retailer) rents during the holiday season and the majority of percentage rent
is recognized in the fourth quarter. As a result of the above, earnings are generally higher in the fourth quarter. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Critical Accounting Policies  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The preparation of financial statements in conformity with generally accepted accounting principles ("GAAP") in the United States of America requires management
to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the
reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period. Actual results could differ from those estimates. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Some
of these estimates and assumptions include judgments on revenue recognition, estimates for common area maintenance and real estate tax accruals, provisions for uncollectible
accounts, impairment of long-lived assets, the allocation of purchase price between tangible and intangible assets, and estimates for environmental matters. The Company's significant
accounting policies are described in more detail in Note&nbsp;2 to the Consolidated Financial Statements. However, the following policies are deemed to be critical. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Revenue Recognition  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Minimum rental revenues are recognized on a straight-line basis over the term of the related lease. The difference between the amount of rent due in a
year and the amount recorded as rental income is referred to as the "straight line rent adjustment." Currently, 53% of the mall and freestanding leases contain provisions for CPI rent increases
periodically throughout the term of the lease. The Company believes that using an annual multiple of CPI increases, rather than fixed contractual rent increases, results in revenue recognition that
more closely matches the cash revenue from each lease and will </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>41</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=43,EFW="2182865",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=101026,FOLIO='41',FILE='DISK124:[08ZAH1.08ZAH70301]DM70301A.;30',USER='KYANGB',CD='26-FEB-2008;20:06' -->
<A NAME="page_dm70301_1_42"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>provide
more consistent rent growth throughout the term of the leases. Percentage rents are recognized when the tenants' specified sales targets have been met. Estimated recoveries from certain
tenants for their pro rata share of real estate taxes, insurance and other shopping center operating expenses are recognized as revenues in the period the applicable expenses are incurred. Other
tenants pay a fixed rate and these tenant recoveries' revenues are recognized on a straight-line basis over the term of the related leases. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Property  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company capitalizes costs incurred in redevelopment and development of properties in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;34 "Capitalization of Interest Cost" and
SFAS No.&nbsp;67 "Accounting for Costs and the Initial Rental Operations of Real Estate Properties." The costs of land and buildings under development include specifically identifiable costs. The
capitalized costs include pre-construction costs essential to the development of the property, development costs, construction costs, interest costs, real estate taxes, salaries and related costs and
other costs incurred during the period of development. Capitalized costs are allocated to the specific components of a project that are benefited. The Company considers a construction project as
completed and held available for occupancy and ceases capitalization of costs when the areas under development have been substantially completed. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Maintenance
and repairs expenses are charged to operations as incurred. Costs for major replacements and betterments, which includes HVAC equipment, roofs, parking lots, etc., are
capitalized and depreciated over their estimated useful lives. Gains and losses are recognized upon disposal or retirement of the related assets and are reflected in earnings. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Property
is recorded at cost and is depreciated using a straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the assets as follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"><TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="82%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Buildings and improvements</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="15%" ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>5-40&nbsp;years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="White" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="82%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Tenant improvements</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="15%" ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>5-7&nbsp;years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="82%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Equipment and furnishings</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="15%" ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>5-7&nbsp;years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Accounting for Acquisitions  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company accounts for all acquisitions in accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards ("SFAS") No.&nbsp;141, "Business Combinations." The
Company first determines the value of the land and buildings utilizing an "as if vacant" methodology. The Company then assigns a fair value to any debt assumed at acquisition. The balance of the
purchase price is allocated to tenant improvements and identifiable intangible assets or liabilities. Tenant improvements represent the tangible assets associated with the existing leases valued on a
fair market value basis at the acquisition date prorated over the remaining lease terms. The tenant improvements are classified as an asset under real estate investments and are depreciated over the
remaining lease terms. Identifiable intangible assets and liabilities relate to the value of in-place operating leases which come in three forms: (i)&nbsp;leasing commissions and legal
costs, which represent the value associated with "cost avoidance" of acquiring in-place leases, such as lease commissions paid under terms generally experienced in the Company's markets;
(ii)&nbsp;value of in-place leases, which represents the estimated loss of revenue and of costs incurred for the period required to lease the "assumed vacant" property to the occupancy
level when purchased; and (iii)&nbsp;above or below market value of in-place leases, which represents the difference between the contractual rents and market rents at the time of the
acquisition, discounted for tenant credit risks. Leasing commissions and legal costs are recorded in deferred charges and other assets and are amortized over the remaining lease terms. The value of
in-place leases are recorded in deferred charges and other assets and amortized over the remaining lease terms plus an estimate of renewal of the acquired leases. Above or below market
leases are classified in deferred charges and other assets or </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>42</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=44,EFW="2182865",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=739551,FOLIO='42',FILE='DISK124:[08ZAH1.08ZAH70301]DM70301A.;30',USER='KYANGB',CD='26-FEB-2008;20:06' -->
<A NAME="page_dm70301_1_43"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>in
other accrued liabilities, depending on whether the contractual terms are above or below market, and the asset or liability is amortized to minimum rents over the remaining terms of the leases. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;When
the Company acquires a real estate property, the Company allocates the purchase price to the components of these acquisitions using relative fair values computed using its estimates
and assumptions. These estimates and assumptions impact the amount of costs allocated between various components as well as the amount of costs assigned to individual properties in multiple property
acquisitions. These allocations also impact depreciation expense and gains or loses recorded on future sales of properties. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Asset Impairment  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company assesses whether there has been impairment in the value of its long-lived assets by considering factors such as expected future operating
income, trends and prospects, as well as the effects of demand, competition and other economic factors. Such factors include the tenant's ability to perform their duties and pay rent under the terms
of the leases. The Company may recognize impairment losses if the cash flows are not sufficient to cover its investment. Such a loss would be determined as the difference between the carrying value
and the fair value of a center. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Deferred Charges  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Costs relating to obtaining tenant leases are deferred and amortized over the initial term of the agreement using the straight-line method. Costs
relating to financing of shopping center properties are deferred and amortized over the life of the related loan using the straight-line method, which approximates the effective interest
method. In-place lease values are amortized over the remaining lease term plus an estimate of renewal. Leasing commissions and legal costs are amortized on a straight-line
basis over the individual remaining lease years. The ranges of the terms of the agreements are as follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"><TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>

<TD WIDTH="3%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="31%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>1-15&nbsp;years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="White" VALIGN="TOP">

<TD WIDTH="3%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

</TR>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Results of Operations  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Many of the variations in the results of operations, discussed below, occurred due to the transactions described above including the 2007 Acquisition Properties,
the 2006 Acquisition Centers, the 2005 Acquisition Centers and the Redevelopment Centers. For the comparison of the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, the
"Same Centers" include all consolidated Centers, excluding the 2007 Acquisition Centers, the 2006 Acquisition Centers and the Redevelopment Centers. For the comparison of the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2006 to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, the Same Centers include all consolidated Centers, excluding the 2006 Acquisition Centers, the 2005 Acquisition Centers and the
Redevelopment Centers. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
the comparison of the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, "Redevelopment Centers" include The Oaks, Twenty Ninth Street, Santa Monica
Place, Westside Pavilion, The Marketplace at Flagstaff Mall, SanTan Village Regional Center and Promenade at Casa Grande. For the comparison of the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 to the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, "Redevelopment Centers" include Twenty Ninth Street, Santa Monica Place and Westside Pavilion. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>43</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=45,EFW="2182865",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=636908,FOLIO='43',FILE='DISK124:[08ZAH1.08ZAH70301]DM70301A.;30',USER='KYANGB',CD='26-FEB-2008;20:06' -->
<A NAME="page_dm70301_1_44"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
comparison of the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, Kierland Commons, Metrocenter Mall, Ridgmar Mall and Tysons Center are referred to
herein as the "Joint Venture Acquisition Centers." Unconsolidated joint ventures are reflected using the equity method of accounting. The Company's pro rata share of the results from these Centers is
reflected in the Consolidated Statements of Operations as equity in income from unconsolidated joint ventures. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Comparison of Years Ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Revenues  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Minimum and percentage rents (collectively referred to as "rental revenue") increased by $34.2&nbsp;million, or 6.7%, from 2006 to 2007. The increase in rental
revenue is attributed to an increase of $17.9&nbsp;million from the 2006 Acquisition Centers, $13.8&nbsp;million from the Redevelopment Centers, $2.0&nbsp;million from the Same Centers and
$0.5&nbsp;million from the 2007 Acquisition Properties. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
amortization of above and below market leases, which is recorded in rental revenue, decreased to $11.7&nbsp;million in 2007 from $13.1&nbsp;million in 2006. The decrease in
amortization is primarily due to leases terminated in 2006. The amortization of straight-lined rents, included in rental revenue, was $10.2&nbsp;million in 2007 compared to $7.8&nbsp;million in
2006. Lease termination income, which is included in rental revenue, decreased to $9.9&nbsp;million in 2007 from $18.0&nbsp;million in 2006. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Tenant
recoveries increased $19.4&nbsp;million, or 7.7%, from 2006 to 2007. The increase in tenant recoveries is attributed to an increase of $11.0&nbsp;million from the 2006
Acquisition Centers, $4.3&nbsp;million from the Redevelopment Centers, $4.0&nbsp;million from the Same Centers and $0.1&nbsp;million from the 2007 Acquisition Properties. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Management Companies' Revenues  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management Companies' revenues increased by $8.3&nbsp;million from 2006 to 2007, primarily due to increased management fees received from the joint venture
Centers, additional third party management contracts and increased development fees from joint ventures. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Shopping Center and Operating Expenses  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Shopping center and operating expenses increased $22.6&nbsp;million, or 8.6%, from 2006 to 2007. Approximately $9.6&nbsp;million of the increase in shopping
center and operating expenses is from the 2006 Acquisition Centers, $6.8&nbsp;million is from the Redevelopment Centers, $6.0&nbsp;million is from the Same Centers and $0.2&nbsp;million is from
the 2007 Acquisition Properties. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Management Companies' Operating Expenses  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management Companies' operating expenses increased to $73.8&nbsp;million in 2007 from $56.7&nbsp;million in 2006, in part as a result of the additional costs
of managing the joint venture Centers and third party managed properties, higher compensation expense due to increased staffing and higher professional fees. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> REIT General and Administrative Expenses  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;REIT general and administrative expenses increased by $3.1&nbsp;million in 2007 from 2006, primarily due to increased share and unit-based
compensation expense in 2007. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Depreciation and Amortization  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation and amortization increased $12.0&nbsp;million in 2007 from 2006. The increase in depreciation and amortization is primarily attributed to an
increase of $10.5&nbsp;million at the Redevelopment Centers, $10.4&nbsp;million at the 2006 Acquisition Centers and $0.2&nbsp;million at the 2007 Acquisition Properties. This increase is offset
in part by a decrease of $5.5&nbsp;million at the Same Centers. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>44</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=46,EFW="2182865",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=593163,FOLIO='44',FILE='DISK124:[08ZAH1.08ZAH70301]DM70301A.;30',USER='KYANGB',CD='26-FEB-2008;20:06' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_do70301_1_45"> </A>

<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"Black" -->


<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"font-family:times;" -->

 </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Interest Expense  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest expense decreased $10.9&nbsp;million in 2007 from 2006. The decrease in interest expense was primarily attributed to a decrease of $17.2&nbsp;million
from term loans, $16.1&nbsp;million from the line of credit, $8.4&nbsp;million from the Same Centers and $2.7&nbsp;million from the Redevelopment Centers. The decrease in interest expense was
offset in part by an increase of $27.3&nbsp;million from the $950.0&nbsp;million convertible senior notes issued on March&nbsp;16, 2007 and $6.6&nbsp;million from the 2006 Acquisition Centers.
The decrease in interest on term loans was due to the repayment of the $250&nbsp;million loan in 2007 and the repayment of the $619&nbsp;million term loan in 2006. The decrease in interest on the
line of credit was due to: (i)&nbsp;a decrease in average outstanding borrowings during 2007, in part, because of the issuance of the senior notes, (ii)&nbsp;a decrease in interest rates because
of the $400&nbsp;million swap and (iii)&nbsp;lower LIBOR rates and spreads. The decrease in interest from the Same Centers is due to: (i)&nbsp;the repayment of the $75.0&nbsp;million loan on
Paradise Valley Mall in January 2007, (ii)&nbsp;an increase in capitalized interest and (iii)&nbsp;a decrease in LIBOR rates on floating rate mortgages payable. The above interest expense items
are net of capitalized interest, which increased to $32.0&nbsp;million in 2007 from $14.9&nbsp;million in 2006 due to an increase in redevelopment activity in 2007. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Equity in Income of Unconsolidated Joint Ventures  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The equity in income of unconsolidated joint ventures decreased $4.6&nbsp;million in 2007 from 2006. The decrease in equity in income of unconsolidated joint
ventures is due in part to a $2.0&nbsp;million loss on sale of assets at the SDG Macerich Properties,&nbsp;L.P. joint venture and additional interest expense and depreciation at other joint
ventures due to the completion of development projects. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Gain on Sale of Assets  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company recorded a gain on sale of assets of $12.1&nbsp;million in 2007 relating to land sales of $8.8&nbsp;million and $3.3&nbsp;million relating to
sale of equipment and furnishings. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Loss on Early Extinguishment of Debt  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company recorded a $0.9&nbsp;million loss from the early extinguishment of the $250&nbsp;million term loan in 2007. In 2006, the Company recorded a loss
from the early extinguishment of debt of $1.8&nbsp;million related to the pay off of the $619&nbsp;million term loan. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Discontinued Operations  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The decrease of $217.8&nbsp;million in income from discontinued operations is primarily related to the recognition of gain on the sales of Scottsdale/101, Park
Lane Mall, Holiday Village, Greeley Mall, Great Falls Marketplace, Citadel Mall, Crossroads Mall and Northwest Arkansas Mall in 2006 (See "Management's Overview and Summary--Acquisitions and
Dispositions"). As result of these sales, the Company classified the results of operations for these properties to discontinued operations for all periods presented. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Minority Interest in the Operating Partnership  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The minority interest in the Operating Partnership represents the 15.0% weighted average interest of the Operating Partnership not owned by the Company during
2007 compared to the 15.8% not owned by the Company during 2006. The change in ownership interest is primarily due to the common stock offering by the Company in 2006, the conversion of partnership
units and preferred shares into common shares in 2007 which is offset in part by the repurchase of 807,000 shares in 2007 (See Note&nbsp;21--Stock Repurchase Program of the Company's Consolidated
Financial Statements). </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>45</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=47,EFW="2182865",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=593409,FOLIO='45',FILE='DISK124:[08ZAH1.08ZAH70301]DO70301A.;30',USER='KYANGB',CD='26-FEB-2008;20:07' -->
<A NAME="page_do70301_1_46"> </A>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Funds From Operations  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Primarily as a result of the factors mentioned above, funds from operations ("FFO")--diluted increased 6.5% to $407.9&nbsp;million in 2007 from
$383.1&nbsp;million in 2006. For the reconciliation of FFO and FFO--diluted to net income available to common stockholders, see "Funds from Operations." </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Operating Activities  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash flow from operations increased to $326.1&nbsp;million in 2007 from $211.9&nbsp;million in 2006. The increase was primarily due to changes in assets and
liabilities in 2007 compared to 2006 and due to the results at the Centers as discussed above. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Investing Activities  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash used in investing activities increased to $865.3&nbsp;million in 2007 from $126.7&nbsp;million in 2006. The increase in cash used in investing activities
was primarily due to a $580.3&nbsp;million decrease in cash proceeds from the sales of assets and a $220.9&nbsp;million increase in capital expenditures. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Financing Activities  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash flow provided by financing activities increased to $355.1&nbsp;million in 2007 from $29.2&nbsp;million in 2006. The increase in cash provided by
financing activities was primarily attributed to the issuance of $950&nbsp;million convertible senior notes issuance in 2007, offset in part by a decrease of $746.8&nbsp;million in proceeds from
the common stock offering in 2006 (See "Liquidity and Capital Resources") and the purchase of the Capped Calls in connection with the issuance of the convertible senior notes in 2007. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Comparison of Years Ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Revenues  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Rental revenue increased by $65.8&nbsp;million or 14.7% from 2005 to 2006. Approximately $43.5&nbsp;million of the increase in rental revenue related to the
2005 Acquisition Centers, $11.9&nbsp;million was related to the 2006 Acquisition Centers and $9.9&nbsp;million was related to the Same Centers due in part to an increase in lease termination
income of $7.2&nbsp;million compared to 2005 at the Same Centers. The increases are offset in part by a decrease in rental revenue of $0.5&nbsp;million at the Redevelopment Centers. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
amount of straight-lined rents, included in rental revenue, was $7.8&nbsp;million in 2006 compared to $6.7&nbsp;million in 2005. This increase is primarily due to the 2006
Acquisition Centers. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
amortization of above and below market leases, which is recorded in rental revenue, increased to $13.1&nbsp;million in 2006 from $11.6&nbsp;million in 2005. The increase in
amortization is primarily due to the 2005 Acquisition Centers and 2006 Acquisition Centers. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Tenant
recoveries increased $39.7&nbsp;million or 18.5% from 2005 to 2006. Approximately $23.0&nbsp;million of the increase in tenant recoveries related to the 2005 Acquisition
Centers, $5.1&nbsp;million related to the 2006 Acquisition Centers and $12.4&nbsp;million related to the Same Centers due to an increase in recoverable shopping center expenses. The increase in
tenant recoveries was offset in part by a decrease of $0.9&nbsp;million at the Redevelopment Centers. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Management Companies' Revenues  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management Companies' revenues increased by $5.3&nbsp;million from 2005 to 2006, primarily due to increased management fees received from the Joint Venture
Acquisition Centers, third party management contracts and increased development fees from joint ventures. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>46</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=48,EFW="2182865",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=919999,FOLIO='46',FILE='DISK124:[08ZAH1.08ZAH70301]DO70301A.;30',USER='KYANGB',CD='26-FEB-2008;20:07' -->
<A NAME="page_do70301_1_47"> </A>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Shopping Center and Operating Expenses  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Shopping center and operating expenses increased $38.2&nbsp;million or 17.1% from 2005 to 2006. Approximately $25.6&nbsp;million of the increase in shopping
center and operating expenses related to the 2005 Acquisition Centers, $5.0&nbsp;million related to the 2006 Acquisition Centers and $8.0&nbsp;million related to the Same Centers offset in part by
a $0.5&nbsp;million decrease at the Redevelopment Centers. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Management Companies' Operating Expenses  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management Companies' operating expenses increased to $56.7&nbsp;million in 2006 from $52.8&nbsp;million in 2005, primarily as a result of the additional
costs of managing the Joint Venture Acquisition Centers and third party managed properties. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> REIT General and Administrative Expenses  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;REIT general and administrative expenses increased by $1.4&nbsp;million in 2006 from 2005, primarily due to increased share-based compensation expense in 2006. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Depreciation and Amortization  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation and amortization increased $31.1&nbsp;million in 2006 from 2005. The increase is primarily attributed to the 2005 Acquisition Centers of
$17.8&nbsp;million, the 2006 Acquisition Centers of $6.2&nbsp;million and the Same Centers of $7.4&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Interest Expense  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest expense increased $37.6&nbsp;million in 2006 from 2005. Approximately $13.8&nbsp;million of the increase relates to the term loan associated with the
2005 Acquisition Centers, $12.4&nbsp;million relates to assumed debt from the 2005 Acquisition Centers, $5.3&nbsp;million relates to the 2006 Acquisition Centers, $13.3&nbsp;million relates to
increased borrowings and higher interest rates under the Company's line of credit, $6.7&nbsp;million relates to higher interest rates on the $250&nbsp;million term loan and approximately
$8.9&nbsp;million relates to increased interest expense due to refinancings and higher rates on floating rate debt regarding the Same Centers. These increases were offset in part by an approximately
$1.3&nbsp;million decrease in interest expense at the Redevelopment Centers and $21.6&nbsp;million relating to the pay off of the acquisition loan associated with the 2005 Acquisition Centers.
Additionally, capitalized interest was $14.9&nbsp;million in 2006, up from $10.0&nbsp;million in 2005. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Equity in Income of Unconsolidated Joint Ventures  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The equity in income of unconsolidated joint ventures increased $9.7&nbsp;million in 2006 from 2005. Approximately $6.5&nbsp;million of the increase relates
to increased income from the Joint Venture Acquisition Centers, increased net income of $3.3&nbsp;million from the Pacific Premier Retail Trust joint venture due to increased rental revenue and
$4.6&nbsp;million from other joint ventures due to increased rental revenues. This is partly offset by a $4.7&nbsp;million increase in interest expense from the SDG Macerich
Properties,&nbsp;L.P. joint venture. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Loss on Early Extinguishment of Debt  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company recorded a loss from the early extinguishment of debt of $1.8&nbsp;million in 2006 related to the pay off of the $619&nbsp;million acquisition
loan on January&nbsp;19, 2006. In 2005, the Company recorded a loss on early extinguishment of debt of $1.7 relating to the refinancing of the mortgage note payable on Valley View Mall. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>47</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=49,EFW="2182865",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=466641,FOLIO='47',FILE='DISK124:[08ZAH1.08ZAH70301]DO70301A.;30',USER='KYANGB',CD='26-FEB-2008;20:07' -->
<A NAME="page_do70301_1_48"> </A>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Discontinued Operations  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The increase of $202.1&nbsp;million in discontinued operations relates to the gain on sales of Scottsdale/101, Park Lane Mall, Holiday Village, Greeley Mall,
Great Falls Marketplace, Citadel Mall, Crossroads Mall and Northwest Arkansas Mall in 2006 (See "Management's Overview and Summary--Acquisitions and Dispositions"). As result of the sales, the Company
reclassified the results of operations for these properties for 2006 and 2005. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Minority Interest in the Operating Partnership  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The minority interest in the Operating Partnership represents the 15.8% weighted average interest of the Operating Partnership not owned by the Company during
2006 compared to the 19.0% not owned by the Company during 2005. The change is primarily due to the stock offering by the Company in January 2006. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Funds From Operations  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Primarily as a result of the factors mentioned above, FFO--Diluted increased 13.7% to $383.1&nbsp;million in 2006 from $336.8&nbsp;million in 2005. For the
reconciliation of FFO and FFO--diluted to net income available to common stockholders, see "Funds from Operations." </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Operating Activities  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash flow from operations decreased to $211.9&nbsp;million in 2006 from $235.3&nbsp;million in 2005. The decrease is primarily due to changes in assets and
liabilities in 2006 compared to 2005 and due to the results at the Centers as discussed above. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Investing Activities  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash used in investing activities decreased to $126.7&nbsp;million in 2006 from $131.9&nbsp;million in 2005. The decrease is primarily attributed to the cash
used to acquire the 2006 Acquisition Centers and increases in development and redevelopment costs at the Centers. This is offset by $610.6&nbsp;million in proceeds from the sale of assets in 2006
(See "Management's Overview and Summary--Acquisitions and Dispositions"). </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Financing Activities  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash flow provided by financing activities was $29.2&nbsp;million in 2006 compared to cash used in financing activities of $20.3&nbsp;million in 2005. The
increase is primarily attributed to the net proceeds of $746.8&nbsp;million from the stock offering in January 2006 offset in part by a reduction of debt in 2006 compared to 2005. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>48</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=50,EFW="2182865",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=705823,FOLIO='48',FILE='DISK124:[08ZAH1.08ZAH70301]DO70301A.;30',USER='KYANGB',CD='26-FEB-2008;20:07' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_dp70301_1_49"> </A>

<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"Black" -->


<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"font-family:times;" -->

 </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>Liquidity and Capital Resources  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company intends to meet its short term liquidity requirements through cash generated from operations, working capital reserves, property secured borrowings,
unsecured corporate borrowings and borrowings under the revolving line of credit. The Company anticipates that revenues will continue to provide necessary funds for its operating expenses and debt
service requirements, and to pay dividends to stockholders in accordance with REIT requirements. The Company anticipates that cash generated from operations, together with cash on hand, will be
adequate to fund capital expenditures which will not be reimbursed by tenants, other than non-recurring capital expenditures. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following tables summarize capital expenditures incurred at the Centers for the years ended December&nbsp;31: </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management
expects similar levels to be incurred in future years for tenant allowances and deferred leasing charges and to incur between $400&nbsp;million to $600&nbsp;million in
2008 for development, redevelopment, expansion and renovations. In January 2008, in a 50/50 joint venture, the Company acquired The Shops at North Bridge, a 680,933 square foot urban shopping center
in Chicago, Illinois, for a total purchase price of $515.0&nbsp;million. The Company's pro rata share of the purchase price was funded by the assumption of a pro rata share of the
$205.0&nbsp;million fixed rate mortgage on the Center and by borrowings under the Company's line of credit. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Capital
for major expenditures, developments and/or redevelopments has been, and is expected to continue to be, obtained from equity or debt financings which include borrowings under the
Company's
line of credit and construction loans. However, many factors impact the Company's ability to access capital, such as its overall debt level, interest rates, interest coverage ratios and prevailing
market conditions. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's total outstanding loan indebtedness at December&nbsp;31, 2007 was $7.6&nbsp;billion (including $1.8&nbsp;billion of its pro rata share of joint venture debt). This
equated to a debt to Total Market Capitalization (defined as total debt of the Company, including its pro rata share of joint venture debt, plus aggregate market value of outstanding shares of common
stock, assuming full conversion of OP Units, MACWH,&nbsp;LP units and preferred stock into common stock) ratio of approximately 53.7% at December&nbsp;31, 2007. The majority of the Company's debt
consists of fixed-rate conventional mortgages payable collateralized by individual properties. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company filed a shelf registration statement, effective June&nbsp;6, 2002, to sell securities. The shelf registration is for a total of $1.0&nbsp;billion of common stock, common
stock warrants or common </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>49</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=51,EFW="2182865",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=100071,FOLIO='49',FILE='DISK124:[08ZAH1.08ZAH70301]DP70301A.;19',USER='GKIBBE',CD='27-FEB-2008;10:14' -->
<A NAME="page_dp70301_1_50"> </A>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>stock
rights. The Company sold a total of 15.2&nbsp;million shares of common stock under this shelf registration on November&nbsp;27, 2002. The aggregate offering price of this transaction was
approximately $440.2&nbsp;million, leaving approximately $559.8&nbsp;million available under the shelf registration statement. In addition, the Company filed another shelf registration statement,
effective October&nbsp;27, 2003, to sell up to $300&nbsp;million of preferred stock. On January&nbsp;12, 2006, the Company filed a shelf registration statement registering an unspecified amount
of common stock that it may offer in the future. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
March&nbsp;16, 2007, the Company issued $950&nbsp;million in convertible senior notes ("Senior Notes") that mature on March&nbsp;15, 2012. The Senior Notes bear interest at
3.25%, payable semiannually, are senior to unsecured debt of the Company and are guaranteed by the Operating Partnership. Prior to December&nbsp;14, 2011, upon the occurrence of certain specified
events, the Senior Notes will be convertible at the option of holder into cash, shares of the Company's common stock or a combination of cash and shares of the Company's common stock, at the election
of the Company, at an initial conversion rate of 8.9702 shares per $1,000 principal amount. On and after December&nbsp;15, 2011, the Senior Notes will be convertible at any time prior to the second
business day preceding the maturity date at the option of the holder at the initial conversion rate. The initial conversion price of approximately $111.48 per share represented a 20% premium over the
closing price of the Company's common stock on March&nbsp;12, 2007. The initial conversion rate is subject to adjustment under certain circumstances. Holders of the Senior Notes do not have the
right to require the Company to repurchase the Senior Notes prior to maturity except in connection with the occurrence of certain fundamental change transactions. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
connection with the issuance of the Senior Notes, the Company purchased two capped calls ("Capped Calls") from affiliates of the initial purchasers of the Senior Notes. The Capped
Calls effectively increase the conversion price of the Senior Notes to approximately $130.06, which represented a 40% premium to the March&nbsp;12, 2007 closing price of $92.90 per common share of
the Company. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company has a $1.5&nbsp;billion revolving line of credit that matures on April&nbsp;25, 2010 with a one-year extension option. The interest rate fluctuates between
LIBOR plus 0.75% to LIBOR plus 1.10% depending on the Company's overall leverage. In September 2006, the Company entered into an interest rate swap agreement that effectively fixed the interest rate
on $400.0&nbsp;million of the outstanding balance of the line of credit at 6.23% until April&nbsp;25, 2011. On March&nbsp;16, 2007, the Company repaid $541.5&nbsp;million of borrowings
outstanding from the proceeds of the Senior Notes (See Note&nbsp;10--Bank and Other Notes Payable of the Company's Consolidated Financial Statements). As of December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006,
borrowings outstanding were $1,015.0&nbsp;million and $934.5&nbsp;million, respectively, at an average interest rate, net of the $400.0&nbsp;million swapped portion, of 6.19% and 6.60%,
respectively. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
May&nbsp;13, 2003, the Company issued $250.0&nbsp;million in unsecured notes maturing in May 2007 with a one-year extension option bearing interest at LIBOR plus
2.50%. On April&nbsp;25, 2005, the Company modified these unsecured notes and reduced the interest rate to LIBOR plus 1.50%. On March&nbsp;16, 2007, the Company repaid the notes from the proceeds
of the Senior Notes (See Note&nbsp;10--Bank and Other Notes Payable of the Company's Consolidated Financial Statements). </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
April&nbsp;25, 2005, the Company obtained a five year, $450.0&nbsp;million term loan bearing interest at LIBOR plus 1.50%. In November 2005, the Company entered into an interest
rate swap agreement that effectively fixed the interest rate of the $450.0&nbsp;million term loan at 6.30% from December&nbsp;1, 2005 to April&nbsp;15, 2010. At December&nbsp;31, 2007 and
2006, the entire loan was outstanding with an interest rate of 6.30%. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
December&nbsp;31, 2007, the Company was in compliance with all applicable loan covenants. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
December&nbsp;31, 2007, the Company had cash and cash equivalents available of $85.3&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>50</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_dp70301_1_51"> </A>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company has an ownership interest in a number of joint ventures as detailed in Note&nbsp;4 to the Company's Consolidated Financial Statements included
herein. The Company accounts for those investments that it does not have a controlling interest or is not the primary beneficiary using the equity method of accounting and those investments are
reflected on the Consolidated Balance Sheets
of the Company as "Investments in Unconsolidated Joint Ventures." A pro rata share of the mortgage debt on these properties is shown in "Item&nbsp;2. Properties--Mortgage Debt." </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition, certain joint ventures also have debt that could become recourse debt to the Company or its subsidiaries, in excess of the Company's pro rata share, should the joint
ventures be unable to discharge the obligations of the related debt. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following reflects the maximum amount of debt principal that could recourse to the Company at December&nbsp;31, 2007 (in thousands): </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Additionally,
as of December&nbsp;31, 2007, the Company is contingently liable for $6.4&nbsp;million in letters of credit guaranteeing performance by the Company of certain
obligations relating to the Centers. The Company does not believe that these letters of credit will result in a liability to the Company. </FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(1)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>See
Note 15&#151;Commitments and Contingencies of the Company's Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></DD></DL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Funds From Operations  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company uses FFO in addition to net income to report its operating and financial results and considers FFO and FFO--diluted as supplemental measures for the
real estate industry and a supplement to GAAP measures. The National Association of Real Estate Investment Trusts ("NAREIT") defines FFO as net income (loss) computed in accordance with GAAP,
excluding gains (or losses) from extraordinary items and sales of depreciated operating properties, plus real estate related depreciation and amortization and after adjustments for unconsolidated
partnerships and joint ventures. Adjustments for unconsolidated partnerships and joint ventures are calculated to reflect FFO on the same basis. FFO </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>51</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=53,EFW="2182865",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=930499,FOLIO='51',FILE='DISK124:[08ZAH1.08ZAH70301]DP70301A.;19',USER='GKIBBE',CD='27-FEB-2008;10:14' -->
<A NAME="page_dp70301_1_52"> </A>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>and
FFO on a fully diluted basis are useful to investors in comparing operating and financial results between periods. This is especially true since FFO excludes real estate depreciation and
amortization as the Company believes real estate values fluctuate based on market conditions rather than depreciating in value ratably on a straight-line basis over time. FFO on a fully
diluted basis is one of the measures investors find most useful in measuring the dilutive impact of outstanding convertible securities. FFO does not represent cash flow from operations as defined by
GAAP, should not be considered as an alternative to net income as defined by GAAP and is not indicative of cash available to fund all cash flow needs. FFO, as presented, may not be comparable to
similarly titled measures reported by other real estate investment trusts. The reconciliation of FFO and FFO--diluted to net income available to common stockholders is provided below. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following reconciles net income available to common stockholders to FFO and FFO--diluted (dollars in thousands): </FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(1)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Calculated
based upon basic net income as adjusted to reach basic FFO. As of December&nbsp;31, 2007, 2006, 2005, 2004 and 2003, 12.5&nbsp;million, 13.2&nbsp;million,
13.5&nbsp;million, 14.2&nbsp;million and 14.2&nbsp;million of aggregate OP Units and Westcor partnership units were outstanding, respectively. The Westcor partnership units were converted to OP
Units on July&nbsp;27, 2004 which were subsequently redeemed for common stock on October&nbsp;4, 2005.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(2)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
computation of FFO--diluted shares outstanding includes the effect of share and unit-based compensation plans and convertible senior notes using the treasury stock method. It also
assumes the conversion of MACWH,&nbsp;LP common and preferred units to the extent that they are dilutive to the FFO computation (See Note&nbsp;12--"Acquisitions of the Company's Notes to the
Consolidated Financial Statements"). On February&nbsp;25, 1998, the Company sold $100&nbsp;million of its Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock. On June&nbsp;16, 1998, the Company sold
$150&nbsp;million of its Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock. On September&nbsp;9, 2003, 5.5&nbsp;million shares of Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock were converted into common shares. On
October&nbsp;18, 2007, 0.6&nbsp;million shares of Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock were converted into common shares. The preferred stock can be converted on a one-for-one
basis for common stock. The then outstanding preferred shares are assumed converted for purposes of 2007, 2006, 2005, 2004 and 2003 FFO--diluted as they are dilutive to that calculation. </FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>52</FONT></P>

<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=54,EFW="2182865",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=214743,FOLIO='52',FILE='DISK124:[08ZAH1.08ZAH70301]DP70301A.;19',USER='GKIBBE',CD='27-FEB-2008;10:14' -->
